rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Entomology and Plant Pathology
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: a Study of the Systematics and Biology of Aphids of the Genus Cinara Curtis in Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The genus Cinara Curtis comprises approximately 175 described species, all of which feed exclusively on coniferous trees and shrubs. The majority of these species occur in the North Temperate Zone, being found in North America, Europe, Asia, the British Isles, North Africa, Japan, Korea and Formosa. A few species occur in the South Temperate Zone of Soutih Africa and Australia. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology and Plant Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Biochemical Studies of Phenylketonuria
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder which was discovered through the association of mental deficiency with the excretion of phenylpyruvic acid. Other names for this condition have ranged from the descriptive but unwieldy "phenylpyruvic oligophrenia" and "imbecillitas phenylpyruvica" to "Folling's disease", after its discoverer. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Passenger Problems of American and Canadian Railroads
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: These words speak of the majesty of the steam engine - but one might also be inclined to think of them as a brief eulogy for the beloved "iron horse." With but a few minor exceptions, the use of diesel locomotion is now predominant on North American railways. One of railroading's most cherished traditions is now but a memory.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics and Political Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: a Dynamical Study of the 1958-59 Stratospheric Polar Vortex
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The circulation of the stratosphere and its relation to the troposphere is presented for the six-month period October, 1958 to March, 1959. The study is based mainly on circumpolar analyses at five-day intervals at the 500-mb, 100-mb and 25-mb levels, supported by numerous space and time sections. Fourier analysis of the circumpolar charts is used to compute energies and energy exchanges after the manner of Lorenz (1955) and unstable wave characteristics following the linear theory of Fleagle (1957). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Meteorology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: the Influence of Gamma-Butyrobetane Esters on Ammonia Metabolism in Brain Tissue Preparations
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1922 Tashiro found that on incubation of frog sciatic nerve under aerobic conditions, a gaseous substance in addition to carbon dioxide was produced. He further showed that this other substance was ammonia, and was able to demonstrate that very small amounts of this substance were liberated as an end product of nerve metabolism under the particular experimental conditions.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Physical, Chemical and Immunological Studies on Antibodies During the Primary, Hyperimmune and Secondary Responses
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The presence of circulating antibody long after the injection of antigen, i.e. viruses, toxoids and bacterial polysaccharides, has frequently been observed. Until recently, however, antibodies produced in response to primary immunization with innocuous soluble protein antigens have been detected in the circulation for relatively short periods of time. It is to be noted that the main types of antibody sought for in these experiments have been precipitins. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: the Transference Numbers of Some Quaternary Ammonium Halides in Nitromethane at 25Â° C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A modified method is described for the measurement of transference numbers. The general applicability of the liquid junction technique of Elias and Schiff to equivalent conductance measurements suggested that the use of liquid junctions in the moving boundary method of Lorimer, Graham and Gordon would allow transference numbers to be measured in any electrolyte. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some Studies on the Metabolism of the 17-Hydroxycorticosteroids in the Human
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The protean findings on patients with adrenocortical tumors and the fact that the adrenal cortex is requisite to life has long been established. Tilesius, in 1803, described obesity, precocious breast development and hirsutism in a girl of four, found to have a tumor of the adrenal cortex. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Familial Environment and Asthmatic Child's Response to Treatment
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Much has been written concerning the origin, diagnosis and treatment of bronchial asthma. Although "asthma has been considered for a long time one of the so-called allergic diseases" it is the "etiological diagnosis of bronchial asthma that presents difficulties."
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Social Work

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: a Study of the Residential Construction Sector in the Canadian Economy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the 35 years from 1926 to the end of 1959, residential construction comprised from 3.23 to 6.71 per cent of gross national income, from 24.9 to 35.8 per cent of total construction activity, and from 14.7 to 21.1 per cent of total public and private investment in Canada. Despite the size of the residential construction sector, Canadian economists have not given it the attention it deserves. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics and Political Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Antigenecity of Casein and Casein Degradation Products
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The anaphylactoid shock in guinea pigs produced by enzymic casein-hydrolysates, has been determined by in vivo test and by the Schultz-Dale technique. It has been shown that hydrolysates with low transmittances are more prone to produce anaphylactoid reaction than hydrolysates with high transmittances. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: la Pensee Politique et Economique d'Emmanuel Mounier
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: La pÃ©riode de l'entre deux guerres est frappÃ©e du sceau de la rÃ©volution. Tout comme le XIXe siÃ¨cle confirmait l'Ã©tablissement du libÃ©ralisme, la rÃ©volution industrielle, les prÃ©tentions dÃ©mocratiques et le nationalisme intransigeant; la pÃ©riode Versailles-Munich marque l'Ã©clatement des cadres posÃ©s au siÃ¨cle dernier. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics and Political Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Spontaneous Polarization Studies in Drill Holes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is a well established fact that numerous mineral deposits exhibit the phenomenon of spontaneous electrical polarization, commonly referred to as SP. The resulting electromotive force is detected by measuring the values of electrical potential at numerous points over the area in question, with respect to a remote point. The measurements are made with non-polarizing electrodes connected to either a D.C. vacuum tube voltmeter or a potentiometer. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: the Aesthetic Consistency of George Moore
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: When George Moore wrote these words in his preface to the revised 1904 edition of his youthful autobiography, he still had almost thirty years to live. On the other hand, he had passed all the crises of his career, domestic, financial, amorous, and literary, and was firmly on the course he was to follow all his remaining years. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the In Vitro Action of ACTH on Corticosteroidogenesis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1716 Montesquieu judged an essay contest on the subject "What is the Use of the Adrenal Glands". Some of the theories advanced were such as "to hold up the stomach, to dilute the urine, to collect the humidities which leak out of the great vessels surrounding them", and so on. Montesquieu decided none of the essays deserved a prize, awarded none.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Positron Lifetimes in the Alkali Halides
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The positron lifetimes in the alkali chlorides and sodium halides have been measured. Two lifetimes have been found in each of these materials, with a small fraction (of the order of a few per cent) of the positrons annihilating with the longer lifetime. The lifetimes vary from material to material much more slowly than do the negative ion radii and the average electronic densities. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Institute of Air and Space Law
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Venezuela's Bilateral Air Transport Agreements and Problems of Interpretation in the Jet Era
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Aviation is dynamic. In air transportation progress constantly outstrips the most optimistic predictions, and the great post-World-War II advances in the aeronautical sciences have produced a new dimension in air transportation: the commercial turbo-jet aircraft. In referring to these new aircraft, one writer states, "It is not adequate to simply say that they are just a faster, bigger aircraft. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Air and Space Law

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Improvements in Weather-Radar Grey Scale
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Improvements have been made in four aspects of grey scale CAPPI displays for weather radars. In order to improve continuity of the echo patterns across the boundary between adjacent CAPPI elements, the gaps between elements have been reduced. The grey scale equipment is now used in such a way that the no-signal areas of the cathode ray tubes do not produce any luminance. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: the Locomotive Engineers' Strike on the Guard Trunk Railway in 1876-1877
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the midst of swirling snow and bitter temperatures, Grand Trunk locomotive engineers and firemen struck work on December 29, 1876. Hundreds of men were involved as this four-day Canadian strike marked the beginning of one of the greatest years of labor unrest in North American history. From the evening of December 29, 1876, to the morning of January 3, 1877, the Grand Trunk men refused to work and tried to persuade others not to take their places. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: History

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: the Effects of Bilingualism on Intelligence
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Whether bilingualism affects intellectual functioning has puzzled psychologists and linguists since as early as the 1920's when Saer (1923) and Smith (1923) reported research on the topic. Numerous studies since then have attempted to determine whether monolingual and bilingual young people differ in intelligence as measured by standard tests. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Henri Poincare's Theory of Conventionalism
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Jules-Henri Poincare (1854-1912) is universally acknowledged to have been one of the greatest scientific minds of the nineteenth century. The development of his genius from childhood precociousness was unusually smooth. By the end of his life he had been accorded virtually every international honour in the field of science.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The glacial geomorphology of the northern Nain-Okak section of Labrador
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The role of Labrador-Ungava as one of the main gathering grounds of the Pleistocene ice caps, and one of the final centres of wastage was recognised as long ago as 1896 by the government geologist A. P. Low. In spite of its obvious importance in the glacial history of North America, Labrador-Ungava has received but scant attention from research workers in the field of glacial geomorphology or geology, due mainly to the inaccessibility and uncertain weather of the peninsula.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geography

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation of verbal behavior to decision formulation in the employment interview
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This is a study of certain aspects of the decision making process in the employment interview. Attention is directed primarily to the relation between verbal behavior in the interview and the interviewerâs decision to employ or not to employ the applicant. Studies of the employment interview have not, in general, been concerned with the manner in which the interviewer reaches his decision. Interest has been focused on the reliability of the decision and on its validity as a predictor of job success. The empirical nature of these studies has resulted partly from concern with the immediate applied problems of improving personnel selection and partly from the difficulty of conceptualizing the development of perceptual and cognitive processes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geographic and occupational wage differentials in Quebec and Ontario
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Public and professional interest in wage determination has, in the past, been occupied with an analysis of the determination of the level of wages, both absolutely and relatively to the rewards of the other factors of production. Consequently any analysis of the wage structure has been given relatively minor attention. But the issue of what the wage structure should be, and how it is determined, is just as important as the larger questions of the determination of the wage level and the distribution of the proceeds of production between the labour and the other factors of production.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Synthesis and behaviour of RNA as shown by radioautography in mouse tissues in vivo
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Progress in the investigation of nucleic acids has been unexpectedly rapid during the past decade. They, like proteins, carbohydrates and fats, have been recognized as indispensable constituents of all living organisms and, indeed, of all tissues. Two, and only two, kinds of nucleic acids, deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), have been identified in living tissues. The morphological evidences of nuclear conjugation at fertilization, and the succeeding nuclear divisions led to the belief that the main genetic material is in the nucleus and consists of the nuclear chromatin.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy
